chapter.htmlHeader: What is the prognosis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• The survival rate for ovarian cancer is strongly related to the stage of the disease at the time of diagnosis. Generally, women diagnosed with early (stage I or II) ovarian cancer have a better one-year survival than those diagnosed with late (stage IV) cancer [Cancer Research UK, 2015; Office for National Statistics, 2016].
  • A statistical bulletin published by the Office for National Statistics on cancer survival by stage at diagnosis reported that in England [Office for National Statistics, 2016]:
    • There was a steadily decreasing survival with increasing stage, but survival for women diagnosed at stage I was high: 99% of women diagnosed at stage I survived the disease for at least one year compared with 51% of women diagnosed at stage IV.
    • Almost 50% of women diagnosed with ovarian cancer were diagnosed at stages III and IV.
    • In 2012–2014, the overall survival rate for women diagnosed with ovarian cancer was 71%. 
  • Cancer Research UK statistics on ovarian cancer reported that [Cancer Research UK, 2015]:
    • Five-year survival for ovarian cancer shows a rapid decrease in survival between stages I and IV. 
      • In 2002–2006, the five-year relative survival ranged from 90% for women diagnosed at stage I to 4% for women diagnosed at stage IV.
    • Of women diagnosed with ovarian cancer in England and Wales in 2010–2011, 35% survived the disease for ten years or more, 46% survived the disease for five years or more, and 73% survived the disease for one year or more.
    • Ovarian cancer survival rate in England was highest for women aged under 40 years at the time of diagnosis.
      • In 2009–2013, almost 90% of women in England diagnosed with ovarian cancer aged 15–39 survived the disease for five years or more compared with 20% of women diagnosed aged 80 years and over.
    • Ovarian cancer survival is improving and has almost doubled in the last 40 years in the UK.
      • In the 1970s, less than 20% of women diagnosed with ovarian cancer survived the disease beyond ten years compared with more than 30% in recent years.
      • Mortality rates for ovarian cancer are projected to fall by 37% in the UK between 2014–2035, to 10 deaths per 100,000 women by 2035.
